story: NewsBrexit: What is Common Market .  Norway Plus model explainedMPs have been voting on a Norway Plus model for a softer Brexit. So what is it, and what would it mean for the UK  Here is the policy explainedShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThe plan, also known as Norway Plus, is one of a barrage that emerged from MPs "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSupport surged in the House of Commons today for a new Brexit option - and itaposs called Common Market ..The plan, also known as aposNorway Plusapos, is one of a barrage that emerged from MPs trying to break the deadlock and push through a softer Brexit .  After Labour announced it would back the plan during indicative votes in the Commons, Common Market .aposs odds of success have lted slightly.It is close to the model backed formally by the Mirror. So what is the plan, what would it mean for Brexit and why will hard Leavers be very, very perturbed  Here are the basics you need to know.  Common Market . is a plan for Brexit put forward by a coalition of MPs, led by Tory backbencher Nick Boles.It would see the UK seek a much softer Brexit than Theresa May is planning - but stop short of full EU membership.Instead Britain would join both the European Economic Areaand the European Free Trade Associationalongside Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. This would mean Britain keeps sovereignty over policies like agriculture and fisheries. But the UK stays in the single market - which would mean we would still have to accept free movement of people. As a member of EFTA, we would however be allowed to impose an emergency brake on immigration should it be shown to be causing social or economic problems. We would also still have to make acontribution to the EU budget. The name is a reference to the form our membership with the continent took decades ago, when it was more focused on trade with less power centralised in Brussels. It would mean negotiating changes to the second part of the Brexit deal, the Political Declaration - but crucially not the first part, the Withdrawal Agreement, which Brussels has said it wonapost change. What does aposNorway Plusapos mean   This Common Market . plan is also known as aposNorway Plusapos. However, what weaposve described above is more or less just the Norway model. So whataposs the Plus bit  Well, this is an added part of the plan referring to a Customs Union. Under the Norway model alone, we would not have a Customs Union with the EU. This would allow us to sign our own trade deals around the world. But it would also force checks on goods crossing Northern Irelandaposs border with the Republic - one of the key reasons Theresa Mayaposs deal broke down. So the MPs behind Common Market . Norway Plus want a special exception from the EFTA agreement to secure a customs arrangement with Brussels. They say this customs arrangement would be either permanent or temporary, depending on the circumstances. This is the Plus bit. The MPs insist the long-term aim of the UK should be to not have a customs union with the EU, but the issue of a frictionless Irish border is crucial. Why have Labour backed Common Market .   Common Market . is not Labouraposs policy, because it is a softer Brexit than Labour was planning. It involves accepting free movement of people, which Labour had repeatedly said would end when we leave the EU, and promised so in the partyaposs  manesto.However, the party whipped MPs to back the proposal during indicative votes on  April , on the basis that it would be better than a No Deal Brexit .Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said although it was not Labour policy, it would allow for a close economic partnership with the EU and is a credible proposition. It is on that basis that we will support it this evening, he said. Will Common Market . become UK policy   Donapost count on it.Before the indicative votes on April , Labour sources were doubtful that it would pass even with the partyaposs backing and that of the SNP .In the first round of voting on March , Common Market . was beaten by  votes with the SNP abstaining and  Labour MPs voting against. That aside though,the policy were to come out on top of indicative votes it would still face a battle to be accepted by Theresa May. It drives a coach and horses through the PMaposs Brexit promises by allowing free movement to continueand having a customs arrangement with the EU. But Tory backbencher Robert Halfon urged the PM to accept the deal, saying it was a strong Brexit that would allow the UK to take back control. And Labour MP Lucy Powell, another architect of Common Market ., said it was vital for the Commons to show what it was for to avoid a No Deal Brexit. We have to break this deadlock before we crash out with No Deal [on April ], she said.

story: NewsBrexit: What has happened in indicative votes drama - and what happens now MPs voted to pave the way for a soft Brexit but all four options failed - AGAIN. Heres what tonights indicative votes meant and what happens next as the deadline to Brexit ticks closerShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video mps-reject--brexit-options-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email MPs have once again rejected ALL FOUR options they chose for Brexit after a string of indicative votes came up with no clear answer.The House of Commons failed to pass plans for a Customs Union by just three votes while the aposNorway Plusapos option - another soft Brexit plan - lost by  votes.And in dramatic scenes Tory MP Nick Boles was close to tears as he resigned from the Conservative Party on the floor of the Commons in a dramatic walkout.Theresa May did not even give a hint of a smile as the results - which had attempted to overturn her own plans - were announced. But Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay once again demanded MPs back Mrs Mayaposs deal to avoid No Deal in just  days. Theresa Mayaposs Cabinet will now meet in the morning to digest the drama before MPs are once again expected to vote on her Brexit deal. Hereaposs where the deadlock sits after tonightaposs drama.  MPs seized control of Commons agenda after Theresa Mayaposs deal was voted down three times. And they used the time to hold indicative votes on four dferent alternative options for Brexit.Two of them were plans for a softer Brexit - either a Customs Union, or the aposCommon Market .apos plan, also known as Norway Plus.The third was for a second EU referendum to let the public confirm any deal MPs agree, or Remain in the EU instead. And the fourth was to revoke Article , the protocol that began the two-year countdown to leaving the EU, in order to hold a public inquiry on whether Brexit should continue. But Brexit was hurled into chaos as not a single one of the options won a Commons majority. Tonightaposs result doesnapost mean the plans are dead at all, but it means no clear way forward has emerged. Results in full Common Market .: FOR  AGAINST  Customs Union: FOR  AGAINST  Second referendum: FOR  AGAINST  Revoke Article : FOR  AGAINST  Tory former minister Nick Boles emotionally quit the party moments after the results were announced. The MP was applauded by Labour and Lib Dem MPs after he quit the Conservative Party after his Brexit alternative plan was defeated for a second time. The architect of the Common Market . plan told MPs: I have given everything to an attempt to find a compromise that can take this country out of the European Union while maintaining our economic strength and our political cohesion. I accept I have failed. I have failed chiefly because my party refuses to compromise. I regret therefore to announce I can no longer sit for this party.  Itaposs prompted new bitter isions in Parliament Bitter Tory Brexiteer Mark Francois gave Chancellor Philip Hammond the message up yours, before adding not so charitably: Iaposm not going to criticise Nick Boles because he fought off cancer.Meanwhile there were angry scenes as Independent Group MP Anna Soubry defended her decision to stick to the pure choice of a second referendum.If she and her  aposTIGapos colleagues had backed a softer Brexit, we would have got a majority for a softer Brexit. But they didnapost - a decision that will enrage other Remainers in the House of Commons. What happens next   The next few days will now be crucial.On Tuesday, Prime Minister Theresa May has five hours to save her career as she holds two back-to-back, marathon Cabinet meetings on how to process the result.On Wednesday or Thursday she could put her deal back to MPs in a farcical FOURTH vote. But unlike the first three, this could pitch her option against the one that comes out on top with MPs. Meanwhile, MPs could try and force the Prime Minister to accept the result by laying legislation in the House of Commons on Wednesday. Something has to be chosen by Wednesday  April - which is when  EU leaders will hold an emergency summit to decide what to do next. If Theresa Mayaposs deal hasnapost passed, she will have three choices - crash out of the EU with no deal revoke Article  and cancel Brexit or negotiate a long delay to leaving. What soft Brexit plans are on the table  Former Tory chancellor Ken Clarke proposed a customs union which means the UK would be able to continue trading freely with the remaining  member states without any checks or duties on goods.It also means all the countries in the EU set the same tarfs on imports from non-EU countries. But its critics say that it would prevent the UK from striking independent trade deals. It lost by  votes.“Norway Plus” would allow close ties to the EU, not as full members but in the single market.It commits us to free movement of people but with an “emergency brake” and we would still have to make reduced contributions to the EU budget. It lost by  votes.  No. Eventhey had got a majority the indicative votes were not legally binding. But with her own deal voted down three times the PM would struggle to ignore Parliamentthey finally agreed on an alternative way forward. She has previously dismissed the prospect of a customs union, but Downing Street yesterday did not rule it out, simply suggesting it was not in the “national interest”. MPs could still try to force their preferred option into law on Wednesday. What does this mean for Theresa May’s deal   It is almost dead, but not quite.The PM still has a huge mountain to climb as she needs to win  more votes from a combination of hardline Brexiteers, the DUP and Labour backbenchers with Leave seats.None are looking like they will budge. MPs are expecting her to have a fourth go at getting her deal through this week.There are also suggestions of a potential run-off between the PM’s deal and a soft Brexit in a bid to focus the minds of rebellious Tory backbenchers.Can the Tory party survive   If Parliament seizes control on Wednesday, forcing the Government to go back to renegotiate the future relationship with Brussels, it would trigger a major crisis in the Tory party.The majority of Tory MPs -  including ten ministers - signed a letter at the weekend saying they would prefer a damaging No Deal Brexit to a softer one.Whichever way the PM turns she faces internal chaos - resignations, splits and even more calls for her to step down immediately. Does it increase the chances of a general election     Most Tory MPs are firmly against a poll to break the deadlock. But No  will keep the option on the table to encourage Brexiteer rebels to back the PM’s deal. However, Parliament would have to vote for it by a two thirds majority - currently looking like a big ask.Jeremy Corbyn could call another no confidence vote in the Government, which could mean another election anywaya handful of Tories back him.The EU will only grant another extension to Brexitthe UK has a firm plan - which could include a general election.

story: NewsMedals and comic reveal how D-Day hero stormed Nazi farmhouse to capture troopsMajor Austin Bobby Joyce won a prestigious military medal - and featured in a comic - after he ran towards a heavily-defended stronghold in  and threw a grenade through its window before his platoon took their captivesShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  APR NewsMajor Austin Joyces medals are now up for sale "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe medals of a D-Day hero whose exploits were immortalised in an adventure comic are now up for sale. Major Austin “Bobby” Joyce led a daring raid on a heavily-defended Nazi farmhouse that ended in the capture of  German troops. After his platoon came under fire he ran towards the building, shot a gunner at the window and threw a hand grenade through it. He and his platoon encircled the house and took  prisoners. He was awarded the Military Medal for the March  raid, dramatised in the July ,  edition of The Victor.  The citation for his medal say: “The speed, resourcefulness and determination of Lance-Sergeant Joyce’s action undoubtedly saved the company many casualties and largely contributed to the success of the attack.” Austin Joyce from Wakefield, West Yorks, enlisted in the West Yorkshire Regiment in  aged . He was believed to have served in the Pacic before transferring to the Welsh Guards in . He was posted to the st Battalion where he was made a non-commissioned officer. They came ashore at Normandy on D-Day, June , , and fought their way through northern France before reaching Germany. There Major Joyce led the farmhouse raid in a village near Essen.  After the war he was stationed in Palestine until . He later served in Japan, Germany, the Arabian Peninsula and Northern Ireland, attaining the rank of major. He was awarded an MBE in  for his service to the Guards Depot at Pirbright in Surrey. His gallantry medals and MBE are tipped to fetch £, at auction next month through Spink  Son in central London. Dad didn’t question the diagnosis – like many people in his generation, he simply took what the doctor told him at face value. It was another  months before he felt the problem was signicant enough toto the surgery and query what had been said.     He was finally referred for tests in December  and quickly diagnosed with prostate cancer. Tragically, by this stage the tumour was already quite advanced and had become inoperable. Despite a course of radiotherapy, within months the cancer was in his lymph nodes and later spread into his back. Ultimately, it was too little, too late. He died in January , aged . I was so angry because when it is caught early, prostate cancer can be treated.     I know things get missed, but Dad’s symptoms should have been such an obvious red flag for a man his age. I can’t believe his GP didn’t refer him on and I can’t help feeling that his lack of action ultimately cost my father his le. That wasted year could have made all the dference. If I’ve learned anything, it’s that no one should be embarrassed to ask for a second opinion or to be referred for teststhey don’t think their GP has made the right call.

story: NewsPlea for eye donors as Brits reveal they are too personal for transplantEXCLUSIVE: More than , people are hoping and waiting for an eye transplant that could help them see again - but these are the organs we are least likely to donateShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  APR NewsRabia has some of her vision back after her corneal eye transplant - hundreds of other patients are waiting for something similar"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTransplant campaigners warn that people needing eye ops face long waits because they are the organs we are least likely to donate. Demand means there needs to be an average  in storage at any one time but the figure is currently  – a % shortfall. title: what happens you eat wetherspoons
story: NewsWhat happens when you eat at Wetherspoons every day for a weekReporter Robin Murray ate at the pub every day for a week - Heres what he foundShareCommentsByRobin Murray:,  APR NewsThe Bristol Post reporter committed to a weeks worth of Spoons meals "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis year marks the th anniversary of a British institution. In  a then unknown Tim Martin opened his first pub aposMartinaposs Free Houseapos, opting to change the name to J.D.Wetherpoon a few weeks after an advertising board fell through the front window during a scuffle. Fast forward to  and Spoons is ubiquitous across the UK, employing , people in  branches.  It is clear that behind the chainaposs remarkable rise to high street power is its cheap drinks and long opening hours.But reporter Robin Murray, from The Mirroraposs sister paper The Bristol Post, attempted to get to the bottom of what  makes the chain so popular. Every day for a week he ate a dferent Bristol Spoons. Here is what he found out:    I should kick off by saying Iaposm a big fan of Spoons. It probably stems from a close relative of mine, whose main aim in le is to visit every J.D. Wetherspoon-owned pub in the country. Considering thereaposs around  of them, Iaposd say itaposs unlikely sheaposll manage it, but thataposs another story for another day. Anyway, given my admiration of the chain, you can probably imagine how quickly my hand shot up when my editor asked all the reporters in the office who would like to do a week-long review of Bristolaposs ious Spoons branches. Add that to the prospect of not having to make sandwiches every evening for a week, and I was well and truly sold. So without further ado, at lunchtime on Monday I left the office and headed to Tim Martinaposs empire for my first of five back-to-back visits, all in the name of research. There was plenty to find out: which is the best of all the clubs  Which Spoons has the best carpet  And how will eating at Spoons five days on the bounce make me feel  This is how I got on. It was a journey... Monday – aposChips cooked to perfectionapos   Spoons of choice:  The Commercial Rooms, Corn Street Meal:  Hummus and roasted vegetable wrap with chips and an orange Sanpellegrino .Given its prime location, Corn Streetaposs Wetherspoon restaurant is the chainaposs flagship Bristol branch, so it felt right to start my week here. Like many Spoons out there itaposs a grandiose building steeped in history, which somewhat juxtaposes what Spoons offers, some might say. Since there are no clubs on Mondays I thought Iaposd get the ball rolling with a veggie option before the unavoidable onslaught of meat came my way. And with a giant mural of Isambard Kingdom Brunel looming over me, I felt like I should order something a little more on the classy side to impress the big man. A hummus and vegetable wrap washed down with a San Pellegrino it was, then. Perhaps naively I thought I was going for a fairly healthy option by swerving a burger or something of that ilk, but my first thought as I bit into the wrap was salt. So much salt. Still, aside from that it wasnapost bad and I couldnapost help but enjoy the overall meal, especially as it came with the luxury of a San Pellegrino - arguably the most premium of all the fizzy beverages. And the chips were cooked to perfection, too - something which I later discovered isnapost always the case. For under a fiver I couldnapost really fault it. The Commercial Rooms got things off to a good start. Tuesday: Steak Club – aposPretty tasty but slightly greasyapos   Spoons of choice:  The Knights Templar, Temple Quay. Meal:  oz sirloin steak with chips and a pint of Shipyard American Pale Ale .This Spoons dfers from most others in Bristol, and indeed across the country, in that it doesnapost quite boast the same impressive architecture and could instead be mistaken as an office by passers-by,it were not for the neon green Spoons sign. Its location means it is often packed with workers from the cluster of nearby offices and commuters. When I went on Tuesday lunchtime there was just a smattering of lonesome diners - myself included. I was pleasantly surprised when the waitress behind the counter asked how Iaposd like my steak cooked, having gone in with the assumption a Spoons steak is a Spoons steak is a Spoons steak. But no, my slab of meat arrived promptlyand cooked as I had asked, and while it obviously wasnapost to the same standard as the cuts you get at the likes of The Ox, Mugshot or Pasture it was pretty tasty,not slightly on the greasy side. The chips were once again very enjoyable, the mushroom and peas were decent too, but the tomato was not. The pint of Shipyard, something youaposd often pay around £ for alone, made the £. fee an absolute steal. I was fairly impressed with the first club of the week. Wednesday: Chicken Club – aposFull yet disappointedapos  Spoons of choice:  The Berkeley, Park Street Meal:  Pulled chicken burger with chips and a pint of diet Pepsi .As a big poultry fan, Chicken Club was the one I was most looking forward to before I embarked on my Wetherspoon journey. The cycle across town to Park Street ramped up my hunger levels a notch or two and I was ravenous when I ordered my pulled chicken burger. My excitement was slightly dampened when I was informed that they had run out of the Jack Daniels honey glaze sauce a colleague had recommended. That was only a minor setback, however, compared with the awful chips that came with my burger. Unlike the previous two days they were disastrously undercooked and some were even stone cold. I probably should have mentioned something to one of the members of staff buzzing about but, given my hunger, I forced them down. The chicken was okay but covered in far too much barbecue sauce, and the bun it was served in was poor - barely toasted and a little on the stale side. I cycled back to the office, full yet disappointed. Chicken club had let me down. Thursday: Curry Club – Curry with a side of plastic Spoons of choice: Knights Templar, Temple Quay Meal: Rogan Josh with naan bread and poppadoms, washed down with a ginger beer . There was one key dference between my visit to the Knights Templar on Tuesday and my Thursday jaunt - on Tuesday there wasnapost a piece of plastic in my food. Yes, thataposs right, there I was happily enjoying my curry when I discovered a piece of plastic packaging underneath my naan bread.The irony is that I was just saying to my girlfriend, who had kindly joined me for lunch, it was the best Spoons meal Iaposd had all week thanks to succulent pieces of lamb and a tasty, perfectly spiced sauce. A minute before unearthing the unwanted item. Undeterred, I cracked on with the meal - having put the plastic to one side - and didnapost bother the waitress with a complaint, despite Rachael advising otherwise. J.D.Wetherspoon has since issued an apology, which is nice, and explained the packaging wasnapost used to wrap any of the mealaposs contents but instead came from a container in the kitchen. Friday: Fish Friday – The best food all week, but the worst service Spoons of choice:  The WG Grace, Whiteladies Road Meal:  Fish and chips with mushy peas and a pint of Brewdog Punk IPA .Before I get stuck into Fridayaposs review, I thought Iaposd describe my Thursday evening jog. I felt incredibly sluggish, having to stop for a walk after only about  minutes. Who knows, maybe it had nothing to do with the Spoons food but usually I feel much fitter when going for a run towards the end of the week, so by my reckoning it was probably the change in diet that made me feel like I was running with lead in my trainers. So thereaposs your aposscientic proofapos,you wanted it, that eating at Spoons every day doesnapost do wonders for your fitness levels. Anyway, The WG Grace proved to be hot and cold. It produced the best food I ate all week by a country mile, but was also where I found the poorest service.    Shortly after taking my seat, a waiter strolled past and plonked a plate of chicken wings in front of me. He was pretty much halfway across the restaurant before I could tell him they werenapost mine. Then a few minutes later a waitress askedthe wrap she was holding was what I had ordered. It wasnapost, so she took it back to the kitchen having not been able to locate its owner. And then, to complete the hat-trick of mishaps, my plate arrived with peas instead of the mushy peas I had ordered. The waitress wasnapost too happy about having to go and get it changed. However once my dish arrived- which I ordered using the impressive Wetherspoon app for the first time - it was top notch. The batter on the fish was nice and flaky and the chips were the best Iaposd eaten all week - far better than the soggy abominations I was served on Wednesday. After finishing my meal I felt a little bit sick, to be honest, and truly stuffed to the brim. I think I was done with Spoons by this point and could tell my body was craving some fruit and veg. What did I learn  The chips DO have an off-day The under-cooked, soggy excuses I was served at The Berkely proved this. More restaurants should adopt Spoonsapos approach to condiments I absolutely HATE those pathetic little pots of Ketchup and other sauces you get served at some restaurants, but at Spoons there are bottles of sauce filled to the brim everywhere you look - and not the cheap stuff, either. Bravo, Tim Martin, bravo.  Spoons carpets are WILD The carpets at Spoons are pretty impressive, arenapost they  I would love to know where they source them from.  Fish club is the best of all the clubs The fish and chips at The WG Grace were pretty darn good, it was just a shame about the shambolic service. Combined with a pint of Brewdog Punk IPA, it was my favourite meal of the week. Plastic and rogan josh isnapost a good combo Fortunately I didnapost eat the bit of plastic that was in my curry on Thursday afternoon, but it was still a little off-putting and made me question the care taken by kitchen staff.  Five days of Spoons isnapost conducive to a healthy lestyle This is hardly surprising, but I did not feel great after eating five Spoons lunches. As I waddled back to the office after my fish and chips on Friday, I was ready for a break from Spoons, dreading my fitness levels for Saturday morningaposs football match. Spoons service is hit and miss Over the week I found the service to be a mixed bag. Some staff were friendly but others were downright rude. The best were at the Berkely worst at the WG Grace.

story: NewsWhat happens to your waistlineyou eat only healthy pre-made meals for a weekOur reporter ate nothing but health, pre-made meals for a week on a quest to find out whether it really would make her feel healthierShareCommentsByAnna Riley:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsReporter Anna Riley ate healthy pre-made meals for a week only like this Piri piri chicken with noodles and veg "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEating healthily can be tough, especially when youaposre in a hurry. title: woman unpacking after holiday horrified
story: NewsWoman unpacking after holiday horried when SCORPION jumps from suitcaseMegan Royle had visited South Africa for her mums wedding, before unpacking at home and spotting the creature scuttling across her bedShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  APR NewsMegan said she was freaking out after her mum told her only the small scorpions are dangerous"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who was unpacking ing home from holiday was horried when a SCORPION jumped from her suircase. Student Megan Royle had visited South Africa for her mumaposs wedding on Sunday, March  While pulling clothes from her case after arriving home in Gillingham, Kent, the creature hopped onto the bed and scuttled away. Megan said: I was rushing to unpack as I was going out to meet friends. Then this tiny scorpion hopped out of the suitcase and scuttled across the bed. “I didn’t clock straight away what it was. I thought to myself: ‘That can’t be a scorpion!’”    Megan had no idea what to do so she rang her mum, still in South Africa, for advice. “Mum told me not to worry, it’s only the little ones that are dangerous,” she said. “And this one was tiny! So then I was freaking out even more!” She also called her friends for help and they contacted the RSPCA. Animal collection officerBrian Milligan went to collect the scorpion. He said: “The scorpion was small and sandy-coloured. It seemed to be well so I took it straight to our specialist exotics centre in Brighton.” Experts at Brighton Reptile Rescue believe the scorpion is an olive thick tail, native to South Africa.    The tiny creature - which is the size of a fingernail - can only be kept in the UK with a Dangerous Wild Animal license as they are highly venomous and can be potentially dangerous. Megan was surprised the creature had survived the -hour, ,km journey from South Africa. “I was just shocked that this little scorpion had made it all of that way,” she added. “I guess I thought airport security would have picked up on it!” While the RSPCA is called to collect dozens of stowaways every year, Brighton Reptile Rescue said they’d never seen this species of scorpion before. ACO Milligan added: “This is actually much more common than people realise and we’re often being asked for help with lizards, snakes, frogs, spiders and even scorpions who have stowed away in unsuspecting holidaymakers’ suitcases or in shipments of fruit.    “As we approach the Easter and summer holidays, we’d urge families to shake out clothes and check suitcases before and during packing to ensure they don’t bring home a surprise souvenir with them! The scorpion is being cared for by experts at Brighton Reptile Rescue and will then be moved to a permanent, specialist home where. The RSPCA would always advise people to treat any unidentied animal with caution until identied accurately and not to try to handle an accidentally imported animal that has been discovered. To help the RSPCA continue rescuing, rehabilitating and rehoming animals in desperate need of care please visit our website.

title: girl contracts horrific infection feet
story: NewsGirl contracts horric infection on feet after walking barefoot through pigstyWARNING: GRAPHIC CONTENT - The -year-old child was diagnosed with Tungiasis, according to the New England Journal of MedicineShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  APR NewsThe girl had played in a pigsty in Brazil "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA little girl caught a ghastly infection on the soles of her feet after walking barefoot through a pigsty. The -year-old had lesions on her feet for days after playing in the mud.Doctors at a primary care clinic in New England, US, diagnosed her with a parasitic infection caused by sand fleas that burrow themselves in the skin, the New England Journal of Medicine says.Her family told medics they had been on holiday in rural Brazil, during which the youngster walked through the pigsty with no shoes on. The infection is known as Tungiasis, caused by fleas native to Central and South America. It typically occurs in remote or poverty-hit areas, medics say.    The female sand flea burrows itself deep into the skin and suck the blood, causing the gruesome lesions to appear.They particularly affect the toes, soles and heels, the World Health Organisationsays.Lesions can become infected with bacteria, which leads to abscesses to form. Within about three weeks, the parasite dies and symptoms begin to regress, according to WHO.  Treatment generally consists of surgically extracting the burrowed sand fleas and then applying topical antibiotic. The WHO estimates around  million people are at risk of Tungiasis in the Americas.Science Magazine reports a researcher from Berlin let a sand flea grow inside her skin to find out whether the parasites mate before or after burrowing.And she found the parasites most likely have sex after females are already inside the host.

title: woman finds love fellow burns
story: NewsWoman finds love with fellow burns survivor after HORRIFIC barbecue accidentWARNING: DISTRESSING CONTENT. Gina Trombino and Tessa Leech fell in love at the Phoenix World Burn CongressShareByIsolde Walters:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsTessa Leechand Gina Trombino together after the ordeals theyve been through "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who nearly died in a terrying barbecue accident said she wouldnapost undo the ordeal after it led her to the love of her le. Gina Trombino, , endured excruciating second and third degree burns on her knees, thighs, stomach, fingers and genitals when she was accidentally sprayed with engine primer and engulfed by flames after lighting a cigarette. She attended a burns survivorsapos congress in September , where she met and fell in love with mother-of-two Tessa Leech. The -year-old had suffered third degree burns to  per cent of her body after her ex- boyfriend sparked industrial cleaner he had thrown on her.    Christopher Rollins, , was jailed for  years for the attack in . Gina and Tessa are now in a long-distance relationship, with Gina planning to move to Christopher, Southern Illinois, to live with Tessa and her two children Patience, , and Jude, three. Amazingly, former restaurant manager Gina says she is happy she went through the engine primer ordeal because it led her to the love of her le. She said: “If I could change what happened to me, I wouldn’t for a split second. “If I hadn’t been set on fire, I wouldn’t have met Tessa.”    Gina attended a barbecue at a friendaposs house in Pleasanton, Calornia, USA in April . After playing baseball with the hostaposs -year-old son the child asked to keep the bat. Gina, of San Francisco, agreed but suggested they spray painted it as it was covered in swear words. The boy accidentally pulled out engine primer instead of paint. “He put the bat between my legs and started spraying,” Gina said. “All the excess was going on my legs and it smelt like something you would rub on an engine.” She told the boy to get the paint instead and when he left, she lit a cigarette. She said: “I had had a few beers and I wasn’t thinking clearly. “It didn’t cross my mind that I shouldn’t light a cigarette.    “There was a tiny gasp, like the sound just before a bonfire catches light, and suddenly flames were leaping from my knees to my stomach. “I was rolling around on the grass but it was making the fire bigger instead of putting the flames out. “I was trying to take my belt off but it was burning my fingers. “I was about to burn to a crisp when suddenly I heard her son say that he had got the child-proof gate to the pool open. “I don’t know how I got the strength, but I stood up, ran and jumped into the pool. “I looked down and I could smell the burning flesh.” Gina finally crawled out of the pool and shuffled into the house. “The fire had gone through my thick black jeans, a pair of board shorts and a pair of underwear,” Gina said. She was put into an induced coma at the Santa Clara Medical Center specialist burns unit and woke up a day later to see her mother, Annette Jones, , beside her. She said: “When I came to, I saw my mother with a worried look on her face. “I looked down and everything was wrapped in gauze.”    Doctors performed three skin grafts where they took skin from Gina’s lower legs, back and buttocks and grafted it onto the burnt parts of her body. “The graft site becomes more painful than the actual burn itself,” Gina said. “It was painful to lay on my back. “In total, I had about  staples that were holding the new skin onto the burns. “My burns went from my knees to my upper thighs, parts of my vagina were burnt. “I had second degree burns on my fingers and third degree burns on my stomach. “The doctor saidI had been on fire for  seconds longer I would have burnt through an artery and bled out.” Gina spent  days in hospital and then ed to Annette’s home, where her recovery was slow and painful. “I still had open wounds and I needed close monitoring, daily showers and daily dressing c hanges for the next three months. “The fire took a lot away from me, including my independence, my ability to look after myself, go to the bathroom and get changed by myself. “I used to love to wear bathing suits in the summer and now there were days when I didn’t even want to go outside.” Gina credited a CBD cream her father, Joe Trombino, , created with his company Scrivano Beauty for helping her burns heal.    She said: “The cream soothed my burns and helped the skin regenerate.” The pair have decided to market the Gina Marie Cream to help other burn survivors. Last September, Gina travelled to Grand Rapids, Michigan, to attend the Phoenix World Burn Congress, the world’s largest gathering of burns survivors, organised by charity the Phoenix Society. She said: “It is probably one of the best things I’ve ever done. “I was scared to go but once I went there and started meeting people, it was tremendously helpful. “It was comforting to know that I was sitting in a group of people who have been through similar situations.” At the three-day event, Gina met Tessa.    Gina said: “When I met her, we were initially just like-minded friends.“After the congress, we stayed in touch through Facebook messages.“I was lucky enough to visit her in January in Southern Illinois. “That’s when we fell in love and we started the foundation of our relationship.” According to Tessa the pair were glued to each other from the moment they met at the confernece.  She added: “I was in awe of her. She was smiling and talking to everybody. “She is one of those people who make you feel better whenever you hang out with them. “She came to see me in January and then I flew to see her in March. “We didn’t plan on falling in love but she’s one of those people it’s impossible not to love.”    While Gina is gay, Tessa has been in relationships with men and women in the past. Tessa’s horric burns came from a domestic violence attack in August  when her ex Rollins poured brake cleaner over her, flicked his lighter and watched as she was engulfed in flames. “Chris just stood there watching me,” she said. “He gave me this look that said, ‘I win, I’ve defeated you.’ “That look gave me the strength to run out of the house and get into the grass and roll around. “I looked at my fingers and they were melting. My skin was dripping off. “My neighbours had run up to me and were asking me to lie down but all I could think was: ‘I don’t have skin’.” Tessa fell into a coma for two months.    “When I woke up in hospital, I said: ‘So it happened, it was real, it wasn’t a nightmare,’” she recalled. “About  percent of my body was covered in third degree burns. “Doctors had to shave what was left of my hair and use the skin on my scalp. “They even used pig skin cells in my skin graft. “The only parts of my body that weren’t burnt were my breasts, my privates and the insides of my elbows.” All of Tessa’s fingers and both her thumbs were amputated. She said: “I have nubbins left. “My ears melted off in the attack but I can still hear. “My motivation and my biggest inspiration was to be able to care of myself so I could get back to my daughter.”    In November  Tessa watched as Rollins was convicted of causing great bodily harm. “The trial was hard. I had to wear full compression guards and a plastic mask over my face,” she said. “I went in every day so that they had to see me and what he had done to me. “I was relieved to see him behind bars but you can’t make sense out of a mindless situation and you can’t understand a monster.” Astonishingly, both Tessa and Gina said they are happy to have gone through their terrying experiences because it led them to one another.    Tessa said: “I wouldn’t be who I am had this terrible thing not happened and now I know Gina, I couldn’t imagine another le without her.” Gina added: “If I had it my way, I would pick up my le right now and move to Illinois to be with her. “I’m speaking out so that other burns survivors know that you deserve love and it will come even after tragedy.”

story: NewsBest April Fools Day pranks and jokes to play on your friends or your boyfriend and kidsIf you want to go all out and pull off these April Fools Day pranks we promise itll be worth itShareCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  APR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video news-explained-brief-history-april-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailItaposs April Foolaposs Day , meaning itaposs the one day of the year where we all agree itaposs perfectly ok for us to be completely cruel and pull pranks on those we love the most. title: a special look at what has been done with the 1 2m dundee decides projects
story: A year on from one of the city’s largest ever “people power” spending projects, the Tele examines just what has been done since Dundee Decides.And council chiefs have revealed a second participatory budget is set to be rolled out next year.The ambitious project handed Dundonians a say on how to spend £. million of their cash.Nearly , people had their say in how Dundee City Council should spend the sum.More than % of the projects voted for by residents are set to be completed by the end of this month.Locals chose from a shortlist of dozens of ideas sourced from the Engage Dundee survey carried out between  and .As part of the project council officers not only held consultation events in community centres, but made efforts to go where they hadn’t before.Armed with tablet computers funded by a government grant, the local authority reached people that have not previously got involved in these kinds of processes.The  projects that locals chose ied from street improvements like dropped kerbs to refurbishment of playparks and new pedestrian crossings.Each was announced to great fanfare in March last year and since then  of the  projects have either been completed or will be by the end of this month.But a number of the projects have been delayed into the next financial year. The council has promised to have them completed quickly, even though it was never intended to have them all completed within  months.Some, like the pedestrian crossing for Arbroath Road, will be completed during the school holidays while the roads are quieter.Others, such as pavement improvements on Albert Street, are going back to the community for further consultation.Those involved in Dundee Decides have hailed the “participatory budgeting” project as a success – likely “one of the most successful of its kind”.The council are so buoyed by its success, they are planning a second round for April  in which locals will not only vote on the ideas but submit them too.Marie Dailly, communities service manager, said: “We’re still looking at what kind of budget might be available – we’re not % sure yet but it will be a signicant amount.“The vast majority of the projectsare either completed or due to be completed by the end of March, or just after.“But, for example, the St Vincent’s play area that was meant to go beside the schooluntil the school is demolished.“What we’ve been able to do is actually improve the park because we will now have a better space for it.“It was never that the projects absolutely had to be finished for now – and there’s absolutely nothing that won’t be done.”In all, about % of eligible locals aged + got involved – and community regeneration manager John Hosie admitted this was “far more” than he or his cohorts had expected.He said: “It got people talking about how much things cost and about the fact they had to make choices about where they wanted the money to go.“We wanted to raise political awareness of the processes involved and people have opened up to the idea of the wider community around them.“The whole benefit of the exercise was to have that conservation with people about why decisions are made.“We don’t just have a button that we press to make things happen.”

story: Aberdeen City Council is on the hunt to find an unsung hero deserving of an award.Nomination have opened for the People’s Champion category in the Star Awards, Aberdeen City Council’s annual celebration of projects, teams and iniduals within the local authority.Members of the public are encouraged to highlight street cleaners, gardeners, housing officers, teachers, road workers, family services, customer care staff or anyone  who works for the council and has made a genuine dference to someone’s le or community.Angela Scott, chief executive of Aberdeen City Council, said: “Our employees are proud to work for the people of Aberdeen.“We hope the public will take this opportunity to recognise the work they do for the city and nominate their People’s Champion.”To nominate someone for the award, an application form can be downloaded from http:bit.ly OxZwAAlternatively, people can email star@aberdeencity.gov.uk to receive a printed copy.Once completed, they should be emailed or posted to Star Awards, Business Hub , Lower Ground Floor North, Marischal College, AB AB.All nominations must be submitted by noon on April .Last year, almost , Evening Express readers took the time to vote for the council employee they thought was worthiest of all.Out of around  nominees, ’s winner was named as Ian Geddes, a -year veteran of the council.Mr Geddes started his employment at the age of .He worked his way up from a lab technician to become co-ordinator of management information systems.Mr Geddes has used his expertise to manage the systems used to log information on children in schools across the city.This year’s Star Awards ceremony will be taking place on June  at the Beach Ballroom.

title: staff at aberdeen offshore firm to remember super puma anniversary
story: Employees at an Aberdeen oil firm were fell silent today as they remember colleagues who lost their lives in the Super Puma crash.Company bosses at KCA Deutag say with the -year anniversary of the incident, their thoughts are with those who lost loved ones.Members of staff at the company’s base on the city’s Bankhead Drive were marking the tragedy.Ten members of staff from the firm died when Flight N crashed into the North Sea.A spokeswoman for KCA Deutag said: “April   was a tragic milestone in the history of KCA Deutag.“On that day we lost  of our much-loved colleagues in the Bond Offshore Helicopter Flight N disaster.“Their lives and those of their friends, families and colleagues were forever changed by the awful events which unfolded that day.“On this, the th anniversary, our thoughts are with all those who lost loved ones and continue to feel the impact of this tragedy.“As a mark of respect, KCA Deutag’s global headquarters in Aberdeen will fell silent at am on Monday April  so we can remember them.“For anyone visiting our headquarters, the memorial to those who lost their lives is a prominent feature in our reception area, and a permanent reminder of the terrible events of April  .”

title: tickets to see john torode and spencer matthews at taste of grampian to go on sale today
story: The countdown is on for a chance to see celebrity chefs including John Torode in action at this year’s Taste Of Grampian – and fans are being urged to get in fast.Tickets for demonstrations by John and other well-known MasterChef faces such as reality TV star Spencer Matthews and Scotland’s National Chef Gary Maclean are expected to be snapped up when they go on sale at am today.Carol Fowler, managing director of Prime Event Management, organisers of Taste Of Grampian, said: “Last year, tickets for James Martin sold out in under an hour. She will be showcasing some delicious patisseries and pastry bakes in Ring  at .pm and .pm.Early bird entry tickets are already on sale for £ at tasteofgrampianearlybirdticket.eventbrite. title: union terrace gardens revamp wont be finished until 2021
story: The revamp of Aberdeen’s Union Terrace Gardens will not be completed for another two years.The project was due to be finished by July, but had been pushed back until .Council chiefs have confirmed they are now aiming for , as they are still to appoint a contractor to deliver the £ million project. vw, px"  The transformation of the Victorian gardens includes creating shop and café spaces in the arches and the installation of water features and community gardens.Work is expected to take at least  months and cost around £m, an increase from the initial price of £m.Council culture spokeswoman Marie Boulton said the authority is expecting a  completion date, and said firms had already expressed an interest in carrying out the work.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. The game will be played at the Ropework or Joint Campus G # weather permitting # with a pm kick off.

title: john crawford ardrishaig
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. As a couple they were permanent fixtures at most shinty events in Argyll and well beyond, particularly at events involving young players.Tribute reproduced courtesy of the Camanachd Association

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: letters week 12
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

The Highland Year of Culture Award for the highest mark in solo woodwind went to Rowan MacDonald for her bassoon rendition of #Easy Tiger# in Friday#s woodwind solo, primary, competition.The Co-operative Membership Cup for the highest mark in solo brass was given to Kintyre#s Jamie Colville.Ann McMillan won the Munro Memorial Salver for the highest vocal solo mark, excluding Gaelic, while the Annabel MacDonald Memorial Quaich for the highest mark in Gaelic solo singing went to Shona Keith.Campbeltown Brass secured the Gford Bowl for the highest mark by a choir or band.The most prestigious award, the Co-operative Premier Festival Award, is chosen by the adjudicators from all of the performances they have heard throughout the week and this year#s winner was Rhona Love from Ardrishaig.Martin Gorringe was delighted with the way the event had gone and said of Fiona MacDonald: #It was Fiona#s last time as festival co-ordinator. title: extra a83 closures loom amid bear scotland operational issues
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowProblems mounted for BEAR Scotland as a resurfacing job near Tarbert was delayed for yet another day # while tarmac laid last month at Inveraray has #an issue with durability# and needs repair.Work to resurface a kilometre-long stretch of the A at Stonefield, Tarbert, started on March  and was originally planned to take four nights # later extended to five nights due to #operational issues#.Trunk road management company BEAR Scotland has now announced that this project is to be extended for a further night. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a £, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.
